messages.text:
what is the optimization in base makes this near zero allocation possible?
```julia> a = [rand(rand(3:8)) for _ = 1:10^3];

julia> @btime sum.($a)
  2.744 μs (1 allocation: 7.94 KiB)```

elements.text: what is the optimization in base makes this near zero allocation possible?

messages.text:
compare to this:
```julia> a = [@SVector rand(rand(3:8)) for _ = 1:10^3];

julia> @btime sum.($a)
  115.129 μs (1493 allocations: 31.31 KiB)```
Can someone make heads or tails of this error? <https://github.com/lorenzoh/DataLoaders.jl/issues/14>

messages.text:
Hi all,

I create a shared array inside a function and fill the elements using @sync @distributed. When I try to access this array later on other workers, I get the following error.

```TaskFailedException:
On worker 2:
BoundsError: attempt to access 0×0×0 Array{Complex{Float64},3} at index [1]```
However, If I re-run the function that creates the shared array and try to access again, I do not get the error. It looks like a shared array takes multiple initializations to be loaded/shared on workers.

Is that correct?

Thanks.

elements.text:
Hi all,

I create a shared array inside a function and fill the elements using @sync @distributed. When I try to access this array later on other workers, I get the following error.

TaskFailedException:
On worker 2:
BoundsError: attempt to access 0×0×0 Array{Complex{Float64},3} at index [1]

However, If I re-run the function that creates the shared array and try to access again, I do not get the error. It looks like a shared array takes multiple initializations to be loaded/shared on workers.

Is that correct?

Thanks.

messages.text:
Hi! I tried to solve differential equations with a bunch of randomly generated initial values and parameters.
Chris Rackauckas said using StaticArrays could speed up calculation in DifferentialEquation.jl. So I tried to generate StaticArrays in each iteration and for each population. Since those calculations are independent, so I tried to use multithreads to accelerate. However, StaticArrays leads to wrong answers. It will mix up when using Threads. So How can I use StaticArrays to faster solve ODE with parallel computing?
I read his tutorial about parallelism (<https://mitmath.github.io/18337/lecture5/parallelism_overview.html>) and tried to generate StaticArray for each thread like this
`u = Vector{typeof(@SVector([1.0,0.0,0.0]))}(undef,1000)`
But for each iteration, the StaticArray needs to be regenerated randomly for initial values, since SVector is immutable, so I could not use it. So is there a way to use StaticArrays to speed up solving ODE with parallel computing?

) and tried to generate StaticArray for each thread like this

messages.text:
Can anyone explain these results?

`julia> xs = rand(1000000);`

`julia> @btime maximum(xs) - minimum(xs)`
  `1.007 ms (3 allocations: 48 bytes)`
`0.9999996733689187`

`julia> @btime -(-(extrema(xs)...))`
  `2.337 ms (5 allocations: 96 bytes)`
`0.9999996733689187`

`julia> @btime extrema(xs)`
  `2.337 ms (1 allocation: 32 bytes)`
`(4.216218330022059e-8, 0.999999715531102)`

`julia> @btime maximum(xs), minimum(xs)`
  `1.009 ms (3 allocations: 64 bytes)`
`(0.999999715531102, 4.216218330022059e-8)`

I would expect the second run to be faster because `extrema()` is supposed to compute the extrema in `O(n)` instead of `O(2n)` as in the first run. And according to the third run, most of the time is spent in calculation of the extrema, so how come it's this slow in comparison to separate computations of the maximum and minimum?

elements.text: I would expect the second run to be faster because
is supposed to compute the extrema in

as in the first run. And according to the third run, most of the time is spent in calculation of the extrema, so how come it's this slow in comparison to separate computations of the maximum and minimum?
same dispatch pattern to multiple methods
? In this example I am avoiding having to define methods for
. This leads to method overwrite warnings when I put this into my module.
What is the recommended way to do this?

messages.text:
Hi All,

Can anybody please help me here?
Why this code does not initiate a sharedarray (x) on all workers?

Thanks.
```using Distributed                                                                                                                                                           

@everywhere using  SharedArrays
addprocs(4)

function start_shared_array(N)
    new = SharedArray{Float64,3}(N, N, N)  

    for i=1:5
        old = deepcopy(new)

        @sync @distributed for j=1:length(new)
            new[j]  = old[j] + 1
        end
    end

    return new
end

x = start_shared_array(2)

println(typeof(x)," ", procs(x) )```

elements.text:
Hi All,

Can anybody please help me here?
Why this code does not initiate a sharedarray (x) on all workers?

Thanks.

using Distributed                                                                                                                                                           

@everywhere using  SharedArrays
addprocs(4)

function start_shared_array(N)
    new = SharedArray{Float64,3}(N, N, N)  

    for i=1:5
        old = deepcopy(new)

        @sync @distributed for j=1:length(new)
            new[j]  = old[j] + 1
        end
    end

    return new
end

x = start_shared_array(2)

println(typeof(x)," ", procs(x) )

messages.text:
is there an elegant way for the following?
 `a = Array{Int64, 1}(undef, 3)`
will initialize a nice Vector/Array populated with zeros "sometimes" ie often when the Julia session is "fresh" (I have come to notice).
But then later on if I do things like  `Array{Int128, 2}(undef, 3,3)` randomness starts to kick in, meaning that the elements seem to hold memory "garbage".
So when you are filling (via indexing)  the Array's elements with values it could lead to random values still being present if I do not address all of the initialized position elements.
That is why my Q is if there is a way for this Vector or Array, when being initialized with a Type, that there is a less "random" placeholder for the `undef` being used eg initialization with `n/a` or something similar that can maybe easily be dropped if I was for instance in a function and returning this or parts of this array? hope my Q is clear ...

messages.text:
I came across a weird compile behaviour that I don't understand. Given the function:
```@inline function num_unique(group_str::AbstractString)
    return group_str |> Set |> length
end```
I have defined a super function (with two variants and their output and lowered code). Variant 1:
```function sum_unique(group_strs::Vector{<:AbstractString})
    # clump groups to one line before adding to set (removes the need for union)
    f = x -> replace(x, "\n" => "")
    return group_strs .|> f .|> num_unique |> sum
end```
Output of variant 1:
```sum_unique(group_strs) = 6703```
Lowered code of variant 1:
```@code_lowered sum_unique(["abaz\nasd", "ashds\ndshgs"])
CodeInfo(
1 ─      #23 = %new(Main.:(var"#23#24"))
│        f = #23
│   %3 = Base.broadcasted(Main.:|>, group_strs, f)
│   %4 = Base.broadcasted(Main.:|>, %3, Main.num_unique)
│   %5 = Base.materialize(%4)
│   %6 = %5 |> Main.sum
└──      return %6
)```
Now the okay-looking (to me) variant 2:
```function sum_unique(group_strs::Vector{<:AbstractString})
    # clump groups to one line before adding to set (removes the need for union)
    return group_strs .|> x -> replace(x, "\n" => "") .|> num_unique |> sum
end```
Output of variant 2:
```sum_unique(group_strs) = [3, 16, 22, 22, ...] # sum(output array) = 6703```
Lowered code of variant 2:
```@code_lowered sum_unique2(["abaz\nasd", "ashds\ndshgs"])
CodeInfo(
1 ─      #27 = %new(Main.:(var"#27#28"))
│   %2 = #27
│   %3 = Base.broadcasted(Main.:|>, group_strs, %2)
│   %4 = Base.materialize(%3)
└──      return %4 # doesn't even call sum and just exits!
)```
I am not sure why this is happening. What is wrong with chaining after an anonymous function?

elements.text: I came across a weird compile behaviour that I don't understand. Given the function:
I have defined a super function (with two variants and their output and lowered code). Variant 1:

function sum_unique(group_strs::Vector{<:AbstractString})
    # clump groups to one line before adding to set (removes the need for union)
    f = x -> replace(x, "\n" => "")
    return group_strs .|> f .|> num_unique |> sum
end

@code_lowered sum_unique(["abaz\nasd", "ashds\ndshgs"])
CodeInfo(
1 ─      #23 = %new(Main.:(var"#23#24"))
│        f = #23
│   %3 = Base.broadcasted(Main.:|>, group_strs, f)
│   %4 = Base.broadcasted(Main.:|>, %3, Main.num_unique)
│   %5 = Base.materialize(%4)
│   %6 = %5 |> Main.sum
└──      return %6
)

function sum_unique(group_strs::Vector{<:AbstractString})
    # clump groups to one line before adding to set (removes the need for union)
    return group_strs .|> x -> replace(x, "\n" => "") .|> num_unique |> sum
end

@code_lowered sum_unique2(["abaz\nasd", "ashds\ndshgs"])
CodeInfo(
1 ─      #27 = %new(Main.:(var"#27#28"))
│   %2 = #27
│   %3 = Base.broadcasted(Main.:|>, group_strs, %2)
│   %4 = Base.materialize(%3)
└──      return %4 # doesn't even call sum and just exits!
)
I am not sure why this is happening. What is wrong with chaining after an anonymous function?

The reason why I use a `Dict{Int,Matrix{Float64}}()`  to store results is because the fetched results is not of constant size and is unknown before calculation.

messages.text:
Hi! I am trying to plot several segments (the image is in the thread) having their start point coordinate and end point coordinate. But it is slow… Any suggestions?
```@recipe function plot(segments::Vector{Segment})

    n = length(segments)
    x = Matrix{Float64}(undef, 2, n) # TODO: compute Float64
    y = Matrix{Float64}(undef, 2, n)

    for (i, segment) in enumerate(segments)
        x[1, i] = segment.xi[1]
        x[2, i] = segment.xo[1]
        y[1, i] = segment.xi[2]
        y[2, i] = segment.xo[2]
    end

    seriestype  :=  :path
    linewidth   --> 0.20
    legend      --> false
    framestyle  :=  :none

    return (x, y)
end```

elements.text: Hi! I am trying to plot several segments (the image is in the thread) having their start point coordinate and end point coordinate. But it is slow… Any suggestions?

@recipe function plot(segments::Vector{Segment})

    n = length(segments)
    x = Matrix{Float64}(undef, 2, n) # TODO: compute Float64
    y = Matrix{Float64}(undef, 2, n)

    for (i, segment) in enumerate(segments)
        x[1, i] = segment.xi[1]
        x[2, i] = segment.xo[1]
        y[1, i] = segment.xi[2]
        y[2, i] = segment.xo[2]
    end

    seriestype  :=  :path
    linewidth   --> 0.20
    legend      --> false
    framestyle  :=  :none

    return (x, y)
end

messages.text:
Can someone explain what `@inline` does in terms of compiler optimizations? I have a function very simple:
```function get_transmission(t) 
    y1 = 0.02414 
    y2 = 0.04025 
    x1 = 0 
    x2 = 157 
    m = (y2 - y1) / (x2 - x1)
    if t < 157
        return m*t + y1
    else 
        return y2
    end
end```
and this function is run many many times in a ODE solver i.e.
```function aModel!(du, u, params, t)
   val = get_transmission(t) 
   # continue solving ODE 
end
solve(aModel!, ...) ```
Now, am I right in thinking that I should annotate this function with `@inline`?

messages.text:
I coded up 3 solutions to Day 15 of Advent of Code (spoilers), and got the following timings:
<https://github.com/lojic/LearningRacket/blob/master/advent-of-code-2020/day15-unsafe-vector.rkt|Racket w/ unsafe vector/arithmetic> => 0.68 seconds
<https://github.com/lojic/LearningRacket/blob/master/advent-of-code-2020/day15.c|C version> => 0.47 seconds
<https://github.com/lojic/LearningRacket/blob/master/advent-of-code-2020/day15.jl|Julia w/ mutable vector> => 0.41 seconds
I was impressed that Julia was faster than C. On the one hand, I haven't coded C seriously since 1996, but on the other, I'm very much a Julia newbie.

I'm just curious if an experienced Julia coder can spot any obvious inefficiencies in the <https://github.com/lojic/LearningRacket/blob/master/advent-of-code-2020/day15.jl|little Julia program> - even though it came in faster than C, that doesn't mean I wouldn't like it to be faster :slightly_smiling_face:

messages.text:
can anyone help me. I'm trying to do a proof of concept and I'm wondering why I keep getting exactly double allocations in the second function than the first
```using DifferentialEquations, Plots, BenchmarkTools
function f1!(du, u, p, t)
    k, V = p
    x, y = u

    r1 = x*k-y*V
    r2 = x*k+y*V 

    du[1] = r1
    du[2] = r2
end

param = [1.05, 1.32]
tspan = (0.0, 10.0)
u0 = [1.0, 2.0]
prob1 = ODEProblem(f1!, u0, tspan, param)

sol1 = @btime solve(prob1)
>> 31.300 μs (384 allocations: 34.08 KiB)```
and I have one where I use a mutable struct to store the intermediates like so
```mutable struct r
    r1::Float64
    r2::Float64
end

function f2!(du, u, p, t, mut)
    k, V = p
    x, y = u

    mut.r1 = x*k-y*V
    mut.r2 = x*k+y*V

    du[1] = mut.r1
    du[2] = mut.r2

end

mut = r(0.0, 0.0)

prob2 = ODEProblem((du,u,p,t) -> f2!(du,u,p,t,mut), u0, tspan, param)

sol2 = @btime solve(prob2)
>>   35.999 μs (664 allocations: 38.44 KiB)```

I have code that does `x += y`  and `x` and `y` are the output of another function (and the same type) and can either be scalars or arrays. I'd rather write `x .+= y`  but this fails when they are scalars what is the best way around this?
```function foo(f::T) where T
  x = f()
  y = f()
  x .+= y
  return x
end
foo(()->[1]) # yay!
foo(()->1) # oh no!```

Hi guys! I want to work with a static size array of structs inside a function. How should I do that?
```function test(...)
  points = SVector{4,Point2D{Float64}}(Point2D(0., 0.), Point2D(0., 0.), Point2D(0., 0.), Point2D(0., 0.))
  ...
end```
Is this the correct approach?

I'm trying install the `SCS` package, and get the following error
```pkg> add SCS
  Resolving package versions...
Downloading artifact: SCS
curl: /home/drm/opt/julia-1.5.1/bin/../lib/julia/libcurl.so.4: no version information available (required by curl)
curl: (60) Cert verify failed: BADCERT_NOT_TRUSTED
More details here: <https://curl.haxx.se/docs/sslcerts.html>

curl failed to verify the legitimacy of the server and therefore could not
establish a secure connection to it. To learn more about this situation and
how to fix it, please visit the web page mentioned above.
Downloading artifact: SCS
curl: /home/drm/opt/julia-1.5.1/bin/../lib/julia/libcurl.so.4: no version information available (required by curl)

More details here: <https://curl.haxx.se/docs/sslcerts.html>

curl failed to verify the legitimacy of the server and therefore could not
establish a secure connection to it. To learn more about this situation and
how to fix it, please visit the web page mentioned above.```
How can I figure out what site has the bad cert?
